unnormalised: Hey everyone, someone asked about how addresses are usually written in India, especially for sending packages and stuff. It's a bit different sometimes, and can be confusing for folks not used to it. So, here's a quick rundown based on my experience.
normalised: Hey everyone, someone asked about how addresses are usually written in India, especially for sending packages and stuff. It's a bit different sometimes, and can be confusing for folks not used to it. So, here's a quick rundown based on my experience.

unnormalised: Firstly, the most basic format usually starts with the house number and building name, like "H.No. 123, Green View Apartments". If there’s no specific building name, you might just have something like "123, Main Street" or "House No. 45, Sector 17". Then comes the street name, area, or landmark. This helps pinpoint the location a bit better. Think something like "near City Hospital, MG Road."
normalised: Firstly, the most basic format usually starts with the house number and building name, like "H.N.O. one hundred and twenty three, Green View Apartments". If there’s no specific building name, you might just have something like "one hundred and twenty three, Main Street" or "House N.O. forty five, Sector seventeen". Then comes the street name, area, or landmark. This helps pinpoint the location a bit better. Think something like "near City Hospital, M.G. Road."

unnormalised: Next, you'll typically include the city and the state. For instance, "Mumbai, Maharashtra". It's super important to include the state as India has a LOT of cities with the same name! And the final piece of the puzzle is the PIN code. It's a 6-digit number, like "400001", and it helps the postal service sort mail super efficiently. Always double-check this, a wrong PIN can cause major delays. Some older folks still write "P.O." before the post office, but that's less common now.

Always double-check this, a wrong P.I.N. can cause major delays. Some older folks still write "P.O." before the post office, but that's less common now.

unnormalised: For apartment complexes, remember to include the flat number! Otherwise, the delivery guy will be wandering around asking everyone! Something like "Flat No. 2B, XYZ Residency" is perfect. And if you're sending something to a rural area, you might need to add the village or taluk (sub-district) details. Some examples of fully written addresses are "Aisha Khan, Flat 201, Gulmohar Apartments, Linking Road, Bandra West, Mumbai, Maharashtra, 400050" or "Ramesh Kumar, H. No. 5, Village Rampur, P.O. Khed, Taluk Junnar, Dist. Pune, Maharashtra, 410502".
